name: Tools and Toys
description: Most of this chapter is dedicated to a mod called Tinkers' Construct. We did not disable the normal Minecraft tools, but the versions in this pack are generally better for various reasons. For one, they can be repaired for much less than remaking the tool. You can upgrade them in other ways. Beyond that, there is a smeltery, which can double your metal yield for ore. Later in the sequence, we will explore steelmaking using electrically-powered machines.

quests.name: Pattern After Me
quests.description: Let's start playing with Tinkers Construct, which is a very ubiquitous Minecraft mod for tools. We will eventually build its smeltery, but we will start with some toolmaking tables and chests. To start making them, create some patterns. By the way, this might be a good time to look at that "Materials And You" book you started with.

tasks.longDescription: Two sticks and two planks diagonally across each other will make 4 patterns. You will use all 4 to make the supporting tables and chest.

These are the basic toolmaking tables. Note that you should really consider placing the pattern chest and the part builder next to each other, since you can see the chest's inventory from the part builder. The easiest way to remember how to make all these is that each is made from one pattern on top of one of four things: a log, a plank, a chest, and a crafting table.

quests.name: Picking From The Parts
quests.description: Let's build a stone pick using Tinkers Construct methods. This pick will be more durable than a base-game stone pick, repairable with one cobblestone, and becomes faster as you wear it down. You can do most of your tunneling with this pick. Make a tool station for yourself to carry around, and you can quickly repair it in tunnels.

tasks.longDescription: You will have to make more patterns. After that, go to the stencil table and place the patterns inside. You can leave them there. Create a pattern each for: pickaxe head, tool binding, and tool rod. You need all three to make a pickaxe.

Take the patterns to the part builder. One at a time, place a pattern in one of the left boxes, and some stone in the right box. You need 1 cobblestone for the head, and half a cobblestone for the binding and rod. If you use cobblestone on one, you'll get a leftover stone piece that you can then use to make the other (binding and rods are half a cobblestone each).

Take the parts over to the tool station. Select the pickaxe template, and fill the parts into the slots. You should see an assembled stone pick in the right-hand slot. It's yours to take now! Oh, if you are feeling creative, you can give the tool a name.

quests.name: Get Thee To A Smeltery!
quests.description: Things are about to get serious. A smeltery is a multiblock furnace that can produce metal ingots twice as efficiently as a Minecraft furnace. It can also cast metal tools that are superior to the base game. Just for doubling ore yield alone, you should build this. The manual will show you a 3x3 smeltery, but you can build a 1x1 to get started. Here we will ask for the materials to build a 1x1, and then reward you with enough to build a comfortable 3x3 (or even larger!).

tasks.longDescription: You will build the bricks for the smeltery out of grout. Two bricks worth of grout are made from one each of sand, clay, and gravel. If you have full stacks of each, you have enough to make a modest smeltery. Remember that you can use the Veinminer key (~ by default) on each of these types of blocks to dig whole veins of them at once. Also consider using a stone shovel from the tool station to do this!
Combine all that sand, gravel, and clay in a crafting screen and you'll get twice as much grout as you had the individual ingredients. Leave one sand aside to make a block of glass.
Run all that grout through a furnace and you'll get seared bricks. Oh, your furnace is taking forever? You can always make more furnaces! How much cobblestone do you have by now?

You probably noticed the Mighty Smelting book in your inventory by this point if you were making all these ingredients. That book explains how to build and operate a smeltery. The requirements for this task are the barest minimum in order to have a functioning smeltery. Note that you don't need to put seared bricks around the corners of the smeltery.

quests.name: Casting Call
quests.description: You can pour 9 ingots worth of metal into a casting basin to make a metal block, but if you just want single ingots, or don't have 9 ingots worth of metal, you will need to pour them into an ingot cast. First, produce aluminum brass by placing 3:1 parts aluminum:copper into the smeltery. Then place a brick or ingot on the casting table. Pour the brass on top of it, and you will make an ingot cast.

quests.name: Bronze Age
quests.description: At this point, you're probably swimming in copper and tin because your picks can pick them up just fine. If you combine 3:1 parts copper:tin, you can make bronze. Bronze is a pretty decent alloy in most cases. It will work comparably to iron for a pick, but it leaves your iron alone to make other things (like a nuclear reactor and steel). Bronze armor will generally keep you safe most of the game.

quests.name: I Pick You!
quests.description: Steel tools mine faster, mine harder, make better armor, and make better swords. It's the good stuff. Oh, and you need steel for your MOON ROCKET. But let's revel in a steel pick for a second. It mines just about everything quickly, and is extremely durable.

tasks.longDescription: You know the drill. Or should I say, you know the pickaxe . . . I can't check if you actually made the pick due to some detection issues in the quest book, so the parts will have to do. Social contract blablabla.

quests.name: Mining Like The Romans
quests.description: Time for a bronze pick. This can blast through most things you'll find, except obsidian, which you can get around for now.

tasks.longDescription: Remember these? Don't make a pick out of them! Create them and then use them for creating casts in the smeltery!
Pour some aluminum brass (or gold, if you are desperate), onto a casting table with the stone parts to make casts.
I can really only check that you made the materials for the pick. There's a bug in the guide that prevents me from checking for the pick itself.

quests.name: The Moss Boss
quests.description: Tools can take modifiers for enhancement. A common one for all tools is moss. Place the tool in the tool station, and then put some moss (made from 9 moss stone) into another slot. Take the goopy-looking tool out. It's ugly, but the tool now **automatically repairs itself over time** when it's in your inventory. You will probably want to save this for a good tool, like one made of bronze, alumite, cobalt, or steel.

quests.name: I Am Not Making A Rapier Joke
quests.description: The longsword is my preferred Tinkers' Construct weapon, but I know a lot of people prefer the rapier. Its base damage is low, so you shouldn't bother making a stone one, but that damage ignores armor. It also stabs very quickly! You can just stab, stab, stab like a psycho! Right-click causes you to quickly leap backwards. This seems dumb, but if you are slick, you can exploit that to jump over certain terrain, although a longsword lets you jump over more.

tasks.longDescription: The guard is the crossbar. Pay special attention to that because the sword guards all look very similar. You will also need a stone tool rod, but that's not unique to this task.
I can't check you made the specific sword, so I'm just checking for the parts. Pour some bronze from the smeltery into these casts on a casting table. You will need a tool rod too.

quests.name: The Forge
quests.description: There are some crazier tools you can make, but you have to upgrade your tool station. A tool forge requires 4 blocks (that's 36 ingots) total. You will want to use the ore for which you have a ton of surplus . . . probably tin or copper.

quests.name: Hammer Time
quests.description: Hammers can mine a 3x3 area around the block that's targeted by it. You could send one of your teammates out on mining duty, and they'd probably come back with everything you need for that moon trip. It's very fast, goes through everything, and also beats the snot out of zombies (smite bonus)!

tasks.longDescription: At this point, you should know the drill. Go to the tool forge, look up the hammer, and see all that stuff you need. You will need lots of steel . . . something like 27 ingots worth. It's worth it though.

quests.name: Beware Of Woodpeckers
quests.description: Wood armor is terrible, but it can help survive a concussive blast from a creeper. Plus, logs should start being commonplace. Tinkers' Construct added wood armor, and since we're talking about that mod now, you might as well start making some of that armor.

quests.name: Steel My Thunder
quests.description: Time to make an ingot of steel. Combine 1 iron ingot with either 4 pulverized charcoal or 2 pulverized coal in the induction smelter. When first using the machine, press the "unlock flux slot" button so you can make this alloy. Normally the induction furnace takes flux materials (sand) to double ingot yield. So it can double ore output just like the smeltery. Sometimes you will get byproducts, and certain additives can actually triple yields!

quests.name: I Induce You Need Steel
quests.description: The rocket will need to be made with some steel. It is an alloy you cannot make from that crude smeltery you probably have built by now. Instead, you will need to use an electrically-powered induction smelter. The steel recipe requires 4 crushed charcoal or 2 crushed coal. For that you will need a pulverizer. You will have to power these machines with redstone flux. See the "electrical power" chapter to get started.

tasks.longDescription: Create the basic versions of the pulverizer and the induction furnace.

quests.name: Let's Get Stoned
quests.description: Arguably, the best tool that's unlocked in the tool forge is the hammer. It will blow out a 3x3 area centered around where you strike. It requires 27 units of material, so it's not cheap. A stone one, however, is. What stone? Well, most of the crap you mine is stone. You are probably strapped for space in your base, so this will clear out most of the gunk. You can then use a superior pick with the veinminer key to knock out the ores. This thing will eat stone alive. Well, it will mine it well but it will also require a steady supply of cobblestone to repair it.

tasks.longDescription: These are all the parts you need for this hammer. Note that you need TWO plates.
Assemble them together in the tool forge. Feel free to name the tool something too. Note, this might trigger if you made a hammer another way. I'm fine with that. A hammer is a hammer.

quests.name: Blinghammer
quests.description: The the previous quest, I was all, "blabla stone hammers can't mine the cool stuff." Well, if you attach a single diamond to that stone hammer in your tool forge, it will be able to mine anything a diamond pick could handle. That is to say . . . just about everything. The durability is still terrible.

tasks.longDescription: I can't check that you specifically made the hammer, so I'll just make sure you had all the pieces to do it. Let's just forge a social contract on this one.

quests.name: Excavate The Premises
quests.description: The excavator is a giant shovel that knocks out a 3x3 area of dirt, sand, or gravel. You don't need it often, but when you do, you *really* need it. This is also the tool of choice if you are digging on the bottom of the ocean to build a sea dome (exercise for the reader).

tasks.longDescription: Usually an excavator is not worth more than being made out of stone, since you won't rely on it too much. You will need (a lot) of cobblestone to repair it. So if you go on a digging frenzy, mine some stone with a pick or hammer sometimes.
You will need a tool forge to assemble this. Note that you can use a regular tool station to repair it. So consider making one of those to carry around with you.

quests.name: Digging Your Own Grave
quests.description: Now we can make a Tinkers Construct shovel. This is like a regular minecraft shovel, except that you can repair it for less resources, and upgrade it if you really wanted to. You probably don't.

tasks.longDescription: You already have the tool rod, so I won't ask for it again.
Tool station. You know the drill.

quests.name: Hatchet Job
quests.description: Let's stop running around with vanilla Minecraft wooden axes. This hatchet is more robust, repairable, and makes a decent early-game sidearm.

tasks.longDescription: You already have the tool rod, so I'm just asking for the axe head.
Take parts to tool station, boom boom. You know the drill.

quests.name: A Mattock Moment
quests.description: The mattock is Tinkers Construct's hoe. It's quite different, really. You can plow the earth with it, dig dirt quickly (although sand and gravel are just like by hand), and chop trees with it. It's very versatile. I still keep a hatchet because it's a better early weapon.

tasks.longDescription: It's quite possible you already have these if you made the other tools first, but if not, take a trip to the stencil table and crank these out.
Making the mattock is a little annoying because you'll have a stone fragment left over. You can use that to repair tools later.
Take parts to tool station, select the mattock, fill it in with the parts . . . you know, like you did with the pick z...z...z...

quests.name: Pulling Your Strings
quests.description: Vanilla Minecraft has a bow, but it kind of stinks. It can't be upgraded consistently, and the thing falls completely apart when it takes enough damage. This shortbow can be repaired by just throwing wood on at at a tool station. You can try your hand at making arrows too, but I recommend using the vanilla recipe. I won't ask to see the bow itself, because there's some bug that makes the bow invisible in the quest book, so it's really confusing.

tasks.longDescription: These stencils are on the RIGHT-HAND side of the stencil table GUI. Stop looking on the left!
Note that you need TWO bow limbs. You can then assemble this in a tool station, although that's an exercise for the reader.

quests.name: Rambo: First Slime
quests.description: A bow made out of slime crystal has a faster draw and a stronger push than a wooden bow. It's a very good bow material. Whether or not you actually make bow limbs from slime crystals is your problem. You should also consider using flamestring, but you have to kill spiders in The Nether to get that stuff. However, that further improves draw and power.

tasks.longDescription: You make slime mud from 4 green slime balls, 1 dirt, and 1 sand. You can use blue slime, but this quest is looking for green. You can get that from green slimes that spawn near swamps, or from some slime trees, which you can get in an earlier quest.
Run the slime mud through the furnace.
Make the bow limbs. You'll have leftovers. It's kind of annoying.

quests.name: Cobbling It Together
quests.description: Let's make the smeltery stupidly huge! You can make the inside of the smeltery as large as 7x7, and then on top of that you can start stacking levels. This pack is really good about finding clay to make all that grout, but you are not so blessed in normal packs in normal terrain generation. Meanwhile, those packs have less resources, which means more stone. You can run cobblestone through your smeltery to make blocks that you can use for the base of a huge smeltery. To make it less tedious, you can compress the cobblestone first, such that each block is really 9 cobblestone in one. It takes 8 cobblestone to make one seared stone block. 2 cobblestone make one brick, but bricks are boring.

tasks.longDescription: If you arrange cobblestone in all 9 cells of a crafting grid, you will get one compressed cobblestone. You can keep going on like that, eventually making octuple-compressed cobblestone. That much cobblestone is something like a large fraction of Pluto's mass. If you are having problems finding cobblestone, consider the "Infinite Cobblestone" quest in the "Post-Scarcity Economy" chapter. That will give you an infinite cobblestone generator in one machine with just a bucket of water and a bucket of lava.

Throw the compressed cobblestone into a smeltery, and be on your way. Note that 7 of them give you 63 stone's worth of material, but you need a clean multiple of 8, so through one regular cobblestone in to balance it out. That gives you 8 seared stones.

quests.name: The Long-Jump Sword
quests.description: You might end up settling on a different sword as your favorite for actually fighting, but the longsword has a great jumping ability. Heck, a stone hatchet is just as effective as an actual weapon. However, if you hold down the right mouse button while holding this sword, it will charge up. When you let go, you will jump. If you jump straight up right as you let go, you can jump very high! I find this indispensable, even for just leaping around my base.

tasks.longDescription: You need a tool rod, a hand guard, and a sword pattern. Pay special attention for the hand guard pattern. They do look alike.
You know the drill. The tool rod and the hand guard cost half a cobblestone each, so you can make one with the scraps from the other.
You know the drill. Fun fact: you can make the longsword even if you pick the wrong sword to make in the tool station.

quests.name: Crossing Paths
quests.description: The crossbow is a new tool to Tinkers' Construct. It is nice because it starts tensioned. When you see a monster, you just pull it out, and the first shot is ready. After the shot, it recharges. An signalum crossbow fires very rapidly. The ammo you use is also important. You want to put moss on it so that the ammo regenerates. Yes, that's a little strange.

tasks.longDescription: The bolts and bindings are iron. The crossbow limb and body is wood (this is what you use to repair it), and the string is ... string. The bolt fletching is feathers. Go yell at some chickens for some feathers!
We are assuming again the bolts are all iron.
